Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Dynamics of Reacting Jets in Cross-Flow

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Gas turbine power plants are a major enabler for both land-based power generation and air-breathing aircraft propulsion. These power plants consist of several components, at the heart of which is the combustor. In a combustor, rapid mixing of air and fuel is required for efficient combustion and cooling of combustor parts. This critical feature constitutes the use of the fluid dynamic benefits of a jet-in-crossflow configuration. In this configuration, a jet is injected in a perpendicular direction to a crossflow, resulting in complex fluid mechanic characteristics that can be leveraged for the above applications. Thus, the broad focus on this project is the fundamental physics in the fluid mechanics and combustion of a jet-in-crossflow configuration. Understanding these physics is critical to the design of the next generation clean and efficient gas turbines for the U.S. aerospace and power generation industries.

The specific objective of the proposed work is to improve the understanding of the dynamics of reacting jets in crossflow. Jets in crossflow are an important fundamental problem that incorporates partially premixed flame propagation in highly strained flows, non-premixed flame autoignition, edge flame propagation, and hydrodynamic stability in reacting flows. It is an important canonical problem where chemical kinetics and hydrodynamic stability of the flow are tightly coupled. This project will focus on two major thrusts. The first thrust will address the question of the impacts of exothermicity and kinetics on the topology and hydrodynamic stability. In particular it will address the question of whether the basic topological flow picture that has been developed in non-reacting flows remain, perhaps with some quantitative adjustments, or whether and when fundamentally new flow dynamics emerge. The second thrust will address flame stabilization processes. This focuses on elucidating the relative roles of flame propagation and autoignition on flame stabilization and spreading in high temperature crossflows. This work will utilize a suite of high frequency planar laser diagnostics at high frame rates. In addition, the research team will also leverage various on-campus programs to promote STEM education and outreach activities.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of the program was to improve understanding of the dynamics of reacting jets in crossflow. Jets in crossflow (JICF) are an important fundamental problem that incorporate partially premixed flame propagation in highly strained flows, non-premixed flame autoignition, edge flame propagation, and hydrodynamic stability in reacting flows. In particular, it is an important canonical problem where chemical kinetics and hydrodynamic stability of the flow are tightly coupled. Due to their rapid mixing characteristics, the applications include gas turbine fuel/air pre-mixers, film cooling jets, dilution air jets, and fluidic flame stabilization. The work performed over the course of this program has made transformational advances in the understanding of the complex interplay of combustion-flow interactions in a jet in cross flow. The project has achieved its goals by using a suite of state of the art, high frequency laser diagnostics in experiments to characterize these interactions and theoretical as well as computational models to better understand how different controlling components play a role in JICF-combustion interactions.

A key focus of this work was understanding the inherently complex interactions between the location of the combustion zone and the shear layers of the JICF. This work has significantly added to the existing literature, by shedding light on the major differences in shear layer dynamics depending on its relative location to the JICF reaction layer. This has important implications on mixing, hydrodynamics and combustion efficiency. Through this effort, we have established a high spatio-temporal resolution three-dimensional optical diagnostic capability that is used in conjunction with a parallel computational effort. The computational effort on test cases helped illustrate the differences in physics for different reaction and shear layer interactions, which were then used to inform the operating conditions for the experiment. This marriage of both high-resolution diagnostics along with the design of experiments through computational simulations is a key outcome of this project for our research group.

The project has resulted in peer-reviewed journal articles and conference papers as well as numerous conference presentations. The project has also resulted in the PI giving invited lectures and tutorials at different conference and workshops. Apart from significant exposure and understanding of high-resolution optical diagnostics and high-fidelity simulations, the graduate student involved in the project has received exposure to the application of the results from this work to real-world designs at industry partners such as Pratt & Whitney. In addition, students from local middle and high schools have visited the university research lab on lab tours as well as high-school teachers have been hosted to expose them to the mathematical and scientific foundations that were applied to this project as well as to foster interest in working towards the issues and problems of energy and environment. Overall, this project has not only advanced the scientific understanding of reacting jet in crossflow dynamics, but also promoted collaboration with industry partners who motivate its application in real-world product development.


Last Modified: 06/29/2020
Modified by: Tim Lieuwen

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The objective of the program was to improve understanding of the dynamics of reacting jets in crossflow. Jets in crossflow (JICF) are an important fundamental problem that incorporate partially premixed flame propagation in highly strained flows, non-premixed flame autoignition, edge flame propagation, and hydrodynamic stability in reacting flows. In particular, it is an important canonical problem where chemical kinetics and hydrodynamic stability of the flow are tightly coupled. The project has achieved its goals by using a suite of state of the art, high frequency laser diagnostics in experiments to characterize these interactions and theoretical as well as computational models to better understand how different controlling components play a role in JICF-combustion interactions. A key focus of this work was understanding the inherently complex interactions between the location of the combustion zone and the shear layers of the JICF. Through this effort, we have established a high spatio-temporal resolution three-dimensional optical diagnostic capability that is used in conjunction with a parallel computational effort. This marriage of both high-resolution diagnostics along with the design of experiments through computational simulations is a key outcome of this project for our research group. The project has also resulted in the PI giving invited lectures and tutorials at different conference and workshops. Apart from significant exposure and understanding of high-resolution optical diagnostics and high-fidelity simulations, the graduate student involved in the project has received exposure to the application of the results from this work to real-world designs at industry partners such as Pratt & Whitney. In addition, students from local middle and high schools have visited the university research lab on lab tours as well as high-school teachers have been hosted to expose them to the mathematical and scientific foundations that were applied to this project as well as to foster interest in working towards the issues and problems of energy and environment. Overall, this project has not only advanced the scientific understanding of reacting jet in crossflow dynamics, but also promoted collaboration with industry partners who motivate its application in real-world product development.
